title: How to Replace Anode Rod in a Hot Water Heater

steps.headline: Shut down supply.
steps.description: Depending on the fuel used for the heater you must first shut off the gas supply to the unit. If it is electric you must shut off the power. This is critical. If you do not shut off the electricity, you will burn out the heating elements in a few seconds. If the heater is oil fired, shut off the motor switch.

steps.headline: Shut off the water supply.
steps.description: You won't want water shooting out all over the place.

steps.headline: If you have sufficient clearance between the top of the heater and the ceiling you may unscrew the the old anode rod from the heater, and remove it.
steps.description: If you do not have the space (at least three (3) feet) you will have to drain the tank. Loosen the anode rod before the next step, it will make life easier.

steps.headline: Disconnect the pipes leading in and out of the tank.
steps.description: Tilt it enough to allow you to remove the old anode rod. Before going to this trouble, verify that your anode rod is not articulated. If it is, you may skip emptying the tank and disconnecting the water connections In the event you do have to drain the tank, disconnect the water and tilt the tank to remove the old rod, consider replacing it with an articulated anode rod. This will make future maintenance much easier.

steps.headline: After you have replaced the rod and before turning the power on, turn the water back on.
steps.description: Verify that you have no leaks.

steps.headline: Turn off the gas or electricity supply.
Turn off the water supply to the tank.
Open the drain at the bottom of the tank.
steps.description: If any large pieces of rust come out, you need to replace the tank. If only discolored then runs a little clearer, drain out a few gallons so there is enough drained to not leak when removing the rod.

steps.headline: It would be helpful to spray some lubricant such as WD-40 around the hex head of the rod, then let it penetrate a few minutes before trying to loosen the rod.
steps.description: You probably will need an impact wrench with a 1-1/16" socket to break it loose. Use short burst to break it loose, then finish turning it out by hand.

steps.headline: If you don't have the clearance above the tank to pull the rod straight up, you can bend the rod as you are pulling it up.
steps.description: This way you don't have to bother with draining the entire tank, removing the plumbing, and tilting the tank.

steps.headline: For the replacement rod you will need a segmented or flexible rod.
steps.description: You can then feed it back in and flex it as needed.

steps.headline: Apply thread sealant to the threads of the rod before starting it back in.
steps.description: Tighten it up snug, but don't over tighten it.

steps.headline: Turn the water supply back on.
steps.description: Then before turning on the power or gas, check for leaks around the rod. If it leaks, tighten it some more until it stops. If it doesn't leak then go ahead and turn a hot water faucet on to let any air escape. After it quits surging, then turn the power or gas back on.

text: Method 1 Shut down supply. Depending on the fuel used for the heater you must first shut off the gas supply to the unit. If it is electric you must shut off the power. This is critical. If you do not shut off the electricity, you will burn out the heating elements in a few seconds. If the heater is oil fired, shut off the motor switch. Shut off the water supply. You won't want water shooting out all over the place. If you have sufficient clearance between the top of the heater and the ceiling you may unscrew the the old anode rod from the heater, and remove it. If you do not have the space (at least three (3) feet) you will have to drain the tank. Loosen the anode rod before the next step, it will make life easier. Disconnect the pipes leading in and out of the tank. Tilt it enough to allow you to remove the old anode rod. Before going to this trouble, verify that your anode rod is not articulated. If it is, you may skip emptying the tank and disconnecting the water connections In the event you do have to drain the tank, disconnect the water and tilt the tank to remove the old rod, consider replacing it with an articulated anode rod. This will make future maintenance much easier. After you have replaced the rod and before turning the power on, turn the water back on. Verify that you have no leaks. Avoiding draining the tank Turn off the gas or electricity supply.  Turn off the water supply to the tank.  Open the drain at the bottom of the tank. If any large pieces of rust come out, you need to replace the tank. If only discolored then runs a little clearer, drain out a few gallons so there is enough drained to not leak when removing the rod. It would be helpful to spray some lubricant such as WD-40 around the hex head of the rod, then let it penetrate a few minutes before trying to loosen the rod. You probably will need an impact wrench with a 1-1/16" socket to break it loose. Use short burst to break it loose, then finish turning it out by hand. If you don't have the clearance above the tank to pull the rod straight up, you can bend the rod as you are pulling it up. This way you don't have to bother with draining the entire tank, removing the plumbing, and tilting the tank. For the replacement rod you will need a segmented or flexible rod. You can then feed it back in and flex it as needed. Apply thread sealant to the threads of the rod before starting it back in. Tighten it up snug, but don't over tighten it. Turn the water supply back on. Then before turning on the power or gas, check for leaks around the rod. If it leaks, tighten it some more until it stops. If it doesn't leak then go ahead and turn a hot water faucet on to let any air escape. After it quits surging, then turn the power or gas back on.
